solution: We first notice that the area of the shaded region is the area of the square minus the areas of the four quarter circles. Each quarter circle has a radius half the side length, so if we sum the areas of the four quarter circles, we have the area of one full circle with radius $5$ cm. Now, we know the area of a square is the square of its side length, so the square has an area of $100 \text{ cm}^2$. A circle has an area of $\pi$ times its radius squared, so the four quarter circles combined have an area of $\pi(5)^2=25\pi \text{ cm}^2$. From this, we know that the area of the shaded region is $\boxed{100-25\pi} \text{ cm}^2$.
model_solution:
To find the area of the shaded region, we need to find the area of the square and subtract the areas of the four quarter circles.

The area of the square is $10^2 = 100$ square centimeters.

The radius of each quarter circle is 5cm because it is a quarter of the square. The area of each quarter circle is $\frac{1}{4}\pi(5)^2 = \frac{25}{4}\pi$ square centimeters.

Since there are four quarter circles, their total area is $4 \times \frac{25}{4}\pi = 25\pi$ square centimeters.

The area of the shaded region is the area of the square minus the area of the four quarter circles, which is $100 - 25\pi$ square centimeters.

Therefore, the area of the shaded region is $\boxed{100 - 25\pi}$ square centimeters.
